snippet: The recent home-cooking movement can stir up feelings of anxiety and guilt for parents as they balance the ideal and the reality of feeding their families.
abstract: Rachel L Swarns The Working Life column on how struggle to prepare fresh, healthy, home-cooked meals frames working lives of many parents in New York City and beyond; notes sociology researchers from North Carolina State University argue efforts to promote home cooking by government officials, celebrity chefs and food writers, may be putting unfair, unrealistic and unhealthy burden on women.
lead_paragraph: The recent home-cooking movement can stir up feelings of anxiety and guilt for parents as they balance the ideal and the reality of feeding their families.

headline.main: Considering the Place of the Working Parent in the Kitchen
headline.print_headline: Considering the Place of the Working Parent in the Kitchen
